;香港特首周日誓言将在为期一周的东盟国家之行中抓住商机，并游说支持加入全球最大的自由贸易协定区域全面经济伙伴关系协定(RCEP)。

;

;行政长官李家超还表示，由10个成员国组成的东南亚国家联盟(东盟)以及更广泛的地区将成为全球最大的经济引擎。

;

;李显龙在开始访问新加坡、马来西亚和印度尼西亚之前发表了上述讲话，代表团由五名高级官员和来自金融、投资、商业、法律、创新科技和物流领域的三十名领导人组成。

;

;李说：“选择东盟的原因是它具有巨大的发展潜力。”李说，该地区去年经济增长5.5％，过去十年平均增长4％。

;

;“随着经济力量从西方向东方的转移，东盟乃至整个亚洲将成为世界最大的经济引擎。我们与东盟签署了自由贸易协定，所以我们已经有了很好的基础。”

;

;他指出此行的重要性，代表团“精神抖擞”，抓住一切机会宣传香港作为营商之地。

;

;行政长官还透露，此行的进一步目标是为香港加入RCEP争取更多支持。RCEP由15个亚太国家组成，其中包括10个东盟国家。

;

;“人们正在李说：“香港作为法律中心的优势是否会被新加坡取代？

;

;“加入RCEP不仅对香港有利，还能让我们为RCEP下的地区做出贡献。”他补充说，香港正从不同方面加强竞争力，包括中国“十四五”规划下八个重点领域的发展。

;

;计划中列出的“八个中心”包括国际金融、创新科技、文化交流、贸易、航运、航空、法律

;

;“我相信，在打下良好的基础后，加入RCEP的机会很大，我会争取各国的支持。”他说。据李说，新加坡、印度尼西亚和马来西亚过去都曾表达过支持，这次访问将用于巩固他们的支持。

;

;香港领导人将在第二次施政报告之前启动公众咨询

;

;中国外交政策负责人王毅本月早些时候在印度尼西亚举行的东南亚外交部长会议上表示支持香港加入贸易集团。他呼吁东盟成员国以及日本和韩国坚持“开放与合作”，加速区域一体化。

;

;此行是李显龙自去年7月上任以来第二次访问东盟国家。

;

;李显龙预计将于周一会见新加坡总理李显龙。在访问这个城市国家后，李明博和他的代表团将于周二前往雅加达，然后于周四抵达吉隆坡。

; Sun, 23 Jul 2023 14:50:02 +0800 Twitter challenger Threads struggles for tractionhttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/united-states-canada/article/3228634/twitter-challenger-threads-struggles-traction?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.23 14:30;
;;

;在最初几天取得巨大成功后，自从 Meta 向 Twitter 发起挑战以来，Threads 的受欢迎程度在几周内有所下降，尽管 Twitter 存在问题，但 Twitter 仍然继续存在。

;

;根据市场分析公司 Sensor Tower 的数据，自 7 月 6 日该平台首次亮相以来，人们每天在 Threads 上花费的平均时间骤降了 75% 以上。

;

;Threads 很快就被计费了。这被认为是 Twitter 的潜在丧钟，这个平台在善变的大亨埃隆·马斯克 (Elon Musk) 的领导下陷入了混乱。

;

;Meta 通过推出竞争对手应用程序 Threads 瞄准 Twitter

;

;该产品的推出在不到五天内就有超过 1 亿用户注册，打破了人工智能工具 ChatGPT 增长最快的消费应用程序的记录，并让逃离 Twitter 的早期采用者感到宽慰和兴奋。

;

;“我实际上关闭了启动 Threads 后就关闭了我的 Twitter 帐户，”布鲁克林居民、一家科技初创公司的营销主管 Lauren Brose 说道。

;

;“我曾经很喜欢 Twitter。埃隆·马斯克接管 Twitter 后，我发现整个环境完全改变了。”

;

;但几周后，Sensor Tower 表示，Threads 的“新注册人数大幅下降”。

;

;Twitter 继续在在线评论和新闻平台领域占据主导地位，硅谷投资者兼分析师 Jeremiah Owyang 表示，马斯克“必须彻底摧毁它”才能永远赶走其受众。

;

;“Threads 会杀死 Twitter 吗？绝对不。他说。

;

;Threads 一经推出就在 100 个国家/地区的 Apple 和 Android 应用商店上线，但由于母公司 Meta 不确定如何遵守欧盟的数据隐私立法，它在欧洲无法使用。

;

;Twitter 被认为拥有约 2 亿普通用户，但自去年特斯拉大亨马斯克收购该平台并解雇了大部分员工以来，它屡屡遭遇技术故障。

;

;马斯克SpaceX 的老板，通过对以前的免费服务收费并允许被禁止的右翼帐户重新回到该平台，疏远了用户。

;

;毫无疑问，与其他想成为 Twitter 的替代品相比，Threads 具有重大优势。

;

;已经出现了几个竞争对手，但大多数都是小众平台，没有能力以必要的规模发展来推翻 Twitter。

;

;但 Meta 能够轻松地促使 Instagram 用户创建 Threads 帐户，利用了至少 10 亿用户的基础。

;

;根据 Insider Intelligence 分析师 Jasmine Enberg 的说法，Threads 有很多东西需要证明，也需要添加很多功能，才能成为 Twitter 的强大替代品。

;

;Enberg 说，它需要培养创作者来吸引用户，并找到自己独立于 Instagram 和 Twitter 的身份。

;

;“鉴于 Twitter 处于混乱状态，他们所做的明智之举是利用 Instagram 现有的社交图谱来快速、无缝地采用，”Owyang谈到 Threads 时，他补充道。

;

;缺点是，这不是“你想与之聊天或写微博”的用户群。

;

;Owyang 指出，Instagram 用户通常是为了图像或视频而不是评论或争议而参与该服务。

;

;Creative Strategies 分析师 Carolina Milanesi 在谈到与 Threads 的比较时表示，“Instagram 上的人群非常不同”。

;

;Twitter 被称为新闻和政治论坛。根据 Threads 和 Instagram 老板 Adam Mosseri 最近发表的一篇文章，Threads 没有兴趣关注的话题。

;

;与此同时，Twitter 被视为记者、名人、运动员、政客和其他人发布帖子的既定大本营。

;

;根据 Milanesi 的说法，Threads 增长的另一个障碍是 Meta 阻碍了它的发展。

;

;“你错过了很大一部分市场，”她在谈到 Threads 缺席时说道。

;

;马来西亚、Meta 将致力于从 Facebook、Instagram 上清除“不良内容”

;

;虽然人们对马斯克旗下的 Twitter 感到失望，但他们正在寻找替代方案，但没有任何一个竞争对手能够将自己确立为理想的选择。

;

;Owyang 推断，Twitter 退出者已经成为某种“侨民”，分布在 Mastodon、Bluesky、Threads 和其他平台上，寻找新的社交媒体家园。

;

;“很多人已经离开 Twitter，而且这种情况还会持续下去，”Owyang 说。

;

;“但问题是他们要去哪里？没有一个集中的地方可以去。”

;

;据 Data.ai Intelligence 称，自推出以来，Threads 应用程序在全球的下载量已超过 1.84 亿次。

;

;“但是，该应用程序在特性/功能方面并未被证明与 Twitter 存在重大差异，”Sensor Tower 高级洞察分析师 Abe Yousef 表示。

;

;“假设人们对 Twitter 的内容政策感到满意，那么什么可以阻止他们继续使用 Twitter？”尤瑟夫补充道。

;一名裸露上身、只穿着热裤和围裙的女子在咖啡馆内摆姿势拍照的视频在网上疯传，中国一家咖啡馆被指控使用色情营销。

;

;来自中国南部广东省省会广州市的这家咖啡馆的图片引起了官方回应、向警方报案，并在大陆社交媒体上引发了关于“着装自由”的激烈辩论。

;

;该图片来自广东省省会广州市的一家咖啡馆。 >;

;7月17日，一段疑似女服务员的F&K咖啡馆旗舰店女子裸露上身的视频被传到网上，引发争议。

;

;她只穿着黑色紧身短裤、高跟鞋，围裙几乎遮不住前部曲线或背部，在咖啡馆的不同区域摆出各种姿势，甚至走进厨房准备饮料。

;

;该视频迅速引起网络关注，女子的围裙也随之而来。导致很多人相信她是店里的女服务员，并引发了对这家店采取色情营销的指责。

;

;有人评论道：“很明显，F&K Cafe 是怕得不到足够的关注，所以他们用这种噱头来自我炒作。”

;

;不过，也有一些倡导着装自由权的人支持这位女士。

;

;一位这样的在线观察者说：“一个普通女孩有什么问题吗？让她回来？我们什么时候才能对女性更加宽容，实现着装自由？”

;

;另一个人同意道：“今年是哪一年？有人还在为女人露背而烦恼吗？那么，对于光着膀子的男人，我们是否也应该一视同仁呢？”

;

;随着公众关注度的加剧，F&K Cafe于7月18日做出回应，否认这名“性感”女子是店员。

;

;他们声称，这些照片是未经授权的人员拍摄的，他们未经许可进入店内，多次被要求离开。

;

;咖啡馆还表示，强烈谴责粗俗行为，将对任何损害咖啡店名誉的恶意人士采取法律行动。

;

;许多网上观察者对咖啡馆的声明仍然不相信：“如果她与你没有联系，为什么你的标志在照片中如此突出？”一位评论者问道。

;

;与此同时，关于着装自由的争论愈演愈烈。

;

;有人辩称：“这不就是一个穿着围裙的裸体人吗？着装自由的前提要求一个人需要穿着。”

;

;“我们甚至可以看到她的乳晕。这是披着自由外衣的暴露狂！”另一个添加了。

;该计划雄心勃勃：邀请 300 名世界顶级冲浪运动员参加今年夏末在南相马北泉海滩举行的新锦标赛，并吸引数千名游客来到日本福岛第一核电站以北约 30 公里的一个小镇，该小镇一直在努力留住居民并吸引游客。

;

;9 级地震十二年后，由于海啸和核电站六座反应堆中三座的熔毁，人们乐观地认为 2023 年北泉冲浪节将使南相马市 — — 以及日本东北部的这一地区 — — 重新回到地图上。

;

;海啸淹没了该镇沿海地区，导致 500 多名当地居民死亡，还有更多人下落不明。尽管核危机的影响可以说更严重，但包括学校、商店、医院和企业在内的当地大部分基础设施在最初的袭击中都被摧毁。

;

;反应堆开始熔化后的几个小时内，该镇被勒令疏散。直到2016年7月，该镇最后剩余部分的疏散令才被解除。即使是现在，悲剧发生前居住在南相马市的人中也只有一小部分已经返回。

;

;为什么值得信赖的日本忽视了福岛蓄水池的安全问题

;

;希望该镇能够利用冲浪活动帮助重建社区的希望已经破灭，因为日本政府决定开始释放经过福岛核电站放射性核素污染处理的水。东京本月早些时候确认，在获得国际原子能机构的支持后，将继续推进排放 120 万吨水。

;

;这一决定引发了包括中国在内的日本邻国、环保组织、日本东北部居民和当地渔民的强烈反对，他们担心自己的渔获将再次卖不出去。

;

;国际冲浪协会 (ISA) 在 3 月份表示，由于担心即将排放的水，它无法正式支持南相马赛事。 “目前对水质潜在影响的不确定性”。

;

;尽管感到失望，但冲浪者和负责推广南相马的委员会仍表现出勇敢的一面，并坚称未来仍然充满希望。

;

;“当我们发现冲浪将首次在日本参加奥运会时，我感到非常兴奋，我认为继续对这项运动的兴奋感非常重要，”55 岁的冲浪协会负责人 Shinji Murohara 说道。福岛冲浪协会。

;

;当地人希望在 2020 年东京奥运会上利用这项运动的成功，其中冲浪是其历史上首次。南相马以南 300 多公里处的千叶市吊崎海滩聚集了大批观众，观看首届比赛。

;

;卡诺亚五十岚在男子短板比赛中获得银牌，安室都筑在女子比赛中获得铜牌，日本成为唯一一个在第一届奥运会冲浪比赛中获得两枚奖牌的国家。

;

;虽然日本拥有许多优秀的冲浪胜地，但国内的游击队球迷欢呼雀跃。南相马市很特别，当地居民室原 (Murohara) 说，他从 18 岁就开始冲浪，并确保自己全年至少每周下水两次。

;

;在 2011 年灾难发生之前，北泉海滩每年夏天都会迎来大约 10 万名当地人和游客、日光浴者和水上运动爱好者。如今，这些海滩的人烟稀少。

;

;“这是本州主岛最东边的地方，从各个方向都能享受到最好的太平洋海浪，”他说。 “全年的海浪都很好，但九月到十一月最好。”

;

;为什么中国、韩国仍然反对福岛污水处理计划？

;

;室原坚称，ISA 尚未完全退出南相马计划的年度赛事，并承诺根据水质测试重新考虑明年的比赛。

;

;福岛核电站的排放预计将持续 20 至 30 年，国际争议的可能性不大一夜之间就消失了，目前还不清楚水要多久才能通过质量测试。

;

;“日本政府已向我们全面通报了处理后水的排放情况，我们理解他们的解释，我们认为这些水是安全的，”室原告诉《亚洲周刊》。

;

;“这里的冲浪者了解情况，他们相信水是安全的，我们想告诉冲浪界的其他人关于南相马市的情况。”

;

;Takahiro Kono，南相马公司负责人该市的冲浪旅游促进委员会呼应了室原的感受，并补充说，计划在今年夏天举办一场规模较小的冲浪节。

;

;今年的比赛将从 9 月 16 日起持续三天，将有 64 名日本冲浪者参加比赛，还有一些外国冲浪者参加展览活动。

;

;“我们期待举办一场精彩的活动，同时也有助于福岛县的重建，”河野说。 “我们希望举办比赛能够促进国内冲浪运动的发展，对福岛有利。”

;

;福岛核电站开始放水后，该市打算邀请一个独立组织对南相马附近的水质进行调查。如果一切顺利，该镇打算再次申请官方认可。

;

;最终目标是举办一项如此著名的赛事，最终可以被称为冲浪世界杯。

;在 6 月份暂停加息之后，人们普遍预计美联储将在周三再次加息，尽管近期出现通胀放缓的迹象，但仍将采取 22 年来最严格的货币立场。

;

;在一年多的时间里连续 10 次加息后，美联储上个月停止了激进的货币紧缩行动，以便让政策制定者有更多时间评估美国经济的健康状况以及近期银行业压力对贷款的影响

;

;此后几周，经济增长的积极升级和通胀数据的降温，增强了美联储利率制定委员会在 7 月 25 日至 26 日投票支持加息 25 个百分点的可能性。

;

;这会将联邦基金利率提高至 5.25% 至 5.5% 之间的区间，这是 2001 年以来的最高水平。

;

;“如果我必须打赌，我打赌他们会将联邦基金利率提高 25%彼得森国际经济研究所 (PIIE) 高级研究员约瑟夫·加格农 (Joseph Gagnon) 表示：“经济正在缓慢降温，”美国银行首席美国经济学家迈克尔·加彭 (Michael Gapen) 在最近的一份投资者报告中写道。

;

;“我们认为大多数委员会成员认为，需要进一步重新平衡供需，以确保通货紧缩继续下去，”他补充道，并解释了为什么他预计周三会再次加息。

;

;现在的期货交易员根据 CME 集团的数据，美联储在下一次会议上加息 25 个基点的可能性超过 99%。

;

;虽然现在普遍预期 7 月加息，但美联储今年需要加息多少才能将通胀率回落至 2% 的长期目标仍然存在疑问。

;

;自美联储决定在 6 月份暂停加息以来，其青睐的通胀指标已同比放缓至 4% 以下，而失业率仍接近历史低点。

;

;由于消费者支出强于预期，第一季度经济增长也大幅上调。

;

;美联储在连续十次加息后暂停加息

;

Why Hong Kong’s visa rules are sending Vietnamese visitors to Asean nationshttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/hong-kong-economy/article/3228622/bad-business-and-leisure-why-hong-kongs-visa-rules-are-sending-vietnamese-visitors-asean-nations?utm_source=rss_feed

;今年六月，胡志明市居民Tracy Ly Kiet Oanh想要与母亲一起来香港，办理旅游签证的手续花了一个月的时间，但这只是获得许可证的麻烦的一部分。

;

;行政经理表示，香港入境处要求她提供过去十年到过的每一个海外地点的记录，以及她的出生证明作为证明文件

;

;“说实话，我忘记了自己去过哪里，尤其是10年前，所以我浏览社交媒体并检索食物和地点的照片作为证据，尽管其中很多都没有露出我的脸，”她说。 “I also don't have any [original] birth certificate, but lucky that my mother keeps my copy.”

;

;Ly and her mother were given tourist visas to enter Hong Kong, but the permits were valid for only seven days and cost HK$230 (US$30) each, while the maximum period of stay for business executives is two weeks.

;

;Travelling elsewhere in the region is far easier for Vietnamese, as they do not need a visa to enter Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, Laos or other countries that belong to the 10-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) trade bloc.

;

;While Ly said she enjoyed Hong Kong and hoped to visit more often, the visa requirement was off-putting.

;

;Business leaders and travel industry stakeholders agree, saying immigration rules are discouraging Vietnamese from visiting at a time when the city is trying to bolster ties with Southeast Asia as part of its post-pandemic recovery efforts.

;

;China's top diplomat backs Hong Kong membership of world's biggest trading bloc

;

;For years, the government has been eyeing membership in the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership, or RCEP, the world's largest free-trade deal that links Asean members with Australia, China, Japan, New Zealand and South Korea.

;

;Winnie Wong Wing-yee, general secretary of the Hong Kong Business Association Vietnam, said in an interview on Thursday that city authorities urgently needed to relax visa requirements or the city could lose business opportunities to regional rivals.

;

;“In the post-pandemic economic recovery, there are companies here that want to send staff to Hong Kong for training, but it is so difficult to apply for a visa for leisure or work purposes that businesses or opportunities will be diverted to Singapore and Malaysia as a result,” said Wong, who has lived and worked in Ho Chi Minh City for the past 18 years.

;

;Ho Chi Minh City, still widely known as Saigon, is home to about 9.3 million people and is the country's financial and cultural hub. Hong Kong has been among its six leading sources of foreign investments over the past decade.

;

;Hong Kong to enter world's largest free-trade pact in Asean partnership

;

;Wong noted that visa requirements for Hong Kong residents visiting Vietnam were eased after the country reopened its borders following the end of Covid-19. Applications can be done electronically and the fees have been halved to US$25.

;

;Connectivity was also boosted on Tuesday when Greater Bay Airlines launched a twice weekly direct flight from Hong Kong. It is the fourth airline after Cathay Pacific Airways, Vietnam Airlines and budget carrier VietJet Air to operate direct flights between the two cities.

;

;Wong said she hoped for a breakthrough in easing the visa rules, pointing to a coming visit by Hong Kong security chief Chris Tang Ping-keung to Hanoi late next month, with travel permit rules one of the items on the agenda.

;

;“We hope the visit will at least shorten the application time for a travel visa, as the application is even more complicated than applying for a visa to the United States and Canada [for Vietnamese],” she said.

;

;A Security Bureau spokesman said Hong Kong's visa policy was subject to review from time to time, while the Vietnamese consulate did not comment on whether the rules were expected to be relaxed for Hongkongers.

;

;Vietnam will ease visa requirements for foreign visitors from 25 countries on August 15, excluding Hong Kong residents.

;

;Tina Phan, Indochina director at the Hong Kong Trade Development Council, agreed the requirements were a burden.

;

;“We have many trade shows in Hong Kong and delegations coming from Ho Chi Minh City or other parts of Vietnam to Hong Kong, but getting a visa [from Hong Kong's authorities] is a problem,” she said.

;

;Greater Bay Airlines launches flights between Hong Kong and Ho Chi Minh City

;

;Danny Sin, assistant general manager of business development at EGL Tours, said Vietnamese authorities should further simplify the visa application for Hongkongers, including payment options.

;

;Sin knew of cases where some credit cards were not accepted on the e-visa application platform even though they were officially recognised as a valid form of settlement.

;

;Sin said he had to pay US$150 for an express e-visa, which still took three working days to receive, after his online payment failed for unknown reasons.

;

;“Unless Hong Kong travellers travel in tour groups, it is challenging for less technology-savvy individuals to apply for the e-visa,” he said.

;

;The Hong Kong Tourism Board regards Vietnam as an emerging destination for residents. Data shows 11,776 Vietnamese travelled to Hong Kong in the first half of this year, or 42 per cent of pre-pandemic levels.

;

;Vietnamese still represent a minority of Hong Kong' total tourist arrivals, with nearly 13 million people visiting during the six-month period, or 37 per cent of pre-Covid levels.

;

;In the first half of 2023, 5.41 million travellers from around the world visited Vietnam, or nearly two-thirds of pre-Covid levels.

;Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jnr will lay down his priorities for the coming months on Monday, closing out his first year in power marked with policies throwing back to his father's two-decade rule.

;

;Marcos Jnr has said he plans to use his second State of the Nation Address before Congress to present a performance report to the public. Days before his speech, his administration set the tone with a slogan: “New Philippines”.

;

;The president has to steer one of Asia's best-performing economies amid a bleak global outlook and domestic challenges that include off-target inflation and elevated borrowing costs. Marcos Jnr has consistently retained wide support from Congress and the public, giving him leeway to push his agenda.

;

;“Marcos's main reason seems to be trying to restore the name of his father,” said Ateneo de Manila University economics professor Leonardo Lanzona. “He's saying that a lot of the programmes of his father were not accomplished, so he's trying to bring them back.”

;

;Several of the Philippine leader's choices and programmes echo those of his father, the late dictator Ferdinand Marcos. For one, his secretaries for the agrarian reform and migrant workers are scions of the elder Marcos' ministers.

;

;Marcos Jnr has also taken a page from his father's playbook as agriculture chief.他的旗舰计划之一名为“卡迪瓦”（Kadiwa）——国家帮助直接向消费​​者出售农产品——于 20 世纪 80 年代老马科斯执政期间首次实施。 Also being revived are rice production and food stamp programmes.

;

;Last week, Marcos Jnr signed a law creating a sovereign wealth fund that is a throwback to the strongman. Its name “Maharlika”, the local word often attributed to nobility, is reminiscent of a guerilla unit that the Marcos Snr supposedly led – a claim historians have since debunked.

;

;Still, the president would need to address current challenges including the risk of El Nino rekindling inflation, said Domini Velasquez, chief economist at China Banking Corp.

;

;“Short-term, addressing inflation concerns should still be top priority,” Velasquez said, adding the risk of prices going up remained. The government should also accelerate its infrastructure push to improve logistics, reduce costs and lower constraints to businesses, she said.

;

;Reforming the military's pension system was another priority for Marcos Jnr, Defence Secretary Gilberto Teodoro said. The nation risked a “fiscal collapse” if the state continued to fully fund soldiers' pensions, finance chief Benjamin Diokno earlier warned.

;

;This reform is among the 20 measures the administration is targeting to pass in Congress. Other legislative priorities include taxing internet transactions, improving the ease of paying taxes, and amending the bank secrecy law to strengthen checks against tax evasion and money laundering.

;

;A mention of military pension reform, along with measures addressing inflation, in Marcos Jnr's speech “could provide a signal to the markets that the macroeconomic fundamentals of the Philippine economy may improve”, HSBC Holdings Plc economist Aris Dacanay said.

;Energy ministers from the Group of 20 meeting in India on Saturday failed to agree on a road map to phase down the use of fossil fuels in the global energy mix.

;

;A final statement after the meeting did not even mention coal, a major contributor to global warming.

;

;Coal is also a key energy source for many developing economies such as India – the world's most-populous country – and China, the world's second-largest economy.

;

;Campaigners were dismayed by the failure to reach agreement in Goa on COP goals including tripling the world's renewable capacity and doubling energy efficiency by 2030.

;

;It came despite G7 leaders agreeing in Hiroshima in May to “accelerate the phase-out of unabated fossil fuels”.

;

;Global temperatures are hitting record highs, triggering floods, storms and heatwaves.

;

;US and China can cooperate on climate policy but tech remains tricky: experts

;

;Explaining the stalemate, G20 president India said that some members had emphasised the importance of seeking a “phase down of unabated fossil fuels, in line with different national circumstances”.

;

;But “others had different views on the matter that abatement and removal technologies will address such concerns,” it added.

;

;Alden Meyer, a senior associate at independent climate think tank E3G, condemned the outcome of the meeting.

;

;“With temperature records being set daily around the world and the impacts of climate change spiralling out of control, the world needed to hear a clarion call to action from the G20 energy ministers,” he said in a statement. “Instead, what we got was very weak tea indeed.”

;

;A coalition of key European Union economies – including Germany and France – and some of the most vulnerable island states this week urged the G20 to accelerate plans to reach net zero emissions and phase out fossil fuels, adding: “Humankind cannot afford to delay”.

;

;They called for greenhouse gas emissions to peak by 2025 at the latest and be cut by 43 per cent by 2030, compared to 2019 levels, in line with recent updates from UN climate experts.

;

;But many developing economies argue that the developed West must pay more as a legacy polluter and greenhouse contributor.

;

;They insist that any transition needs huge capital and new technology, while giving up on polluting fuels without affordable alternatives will condemn their huge populations to poverty.

;

;G20 host nation India is itself only pledging to reach net zero by 2070, 20 years later than the commitment made by many other countries.

;

;A report prepared for its G20 presidency estimated the cost of the energy transition at US$4 trillion a year and emphasised the importance of low-cost financing for developing countries and technology transfers – a key demand of New Delhi's.

;

;Some major oil producers have also resisted a quick transition away from fossil fuels.

;

;Ed King from the climate-oriented communications firm GSCC blamed Russia and Saudi Arabia for a lack of progress at the meeting.

;

;China will determine its own path to carbon reduction: Xi Jinping

;

;They had “blocked efforts to land agreement on tripling clean energy, targeting fossil fuel cuts,” King tweeted.

;

;Sultan Al Jaber, the chief executive of the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company who will head the COP28 talks, has said he expects fossil fuels to continue to play a role with the use of often controversial technologies to “abate”, or neutralise, the emissions.

;

;He has said that a phase down of fossil fuels is both “inevitable” and “essential”, but has been reluctant to spell out a time frame.

;Taiwan is facing a new diplomatic challenge, with a move to revoke its permanent observer status at the Central American Parliament to make way for Beijing.

;

;The proposal – made by Nicaragua – comes as Taipei is keeping a wary eye on next month's presidential run-off in Guatemala, where a contender has promised closer ties with Beijing if elected.

;

;Taiwan's diplomatic presence in Central America could be largely wiped out if it loses both observer status in the regional body and formal recognition from Guatemala, one of its few remaining allies.

;

;The parliament, known as Parlacen, is based in Guatemala and the country is the only member that still has official ties with Taiwan. The others – El Salvador, the Dominican Republic, Honduras, Nicaragua and Panama – have all switched diplomatic recognition to Beijing in recent years.

;

;Taiwan has since 1999 been one of five permanent observers – along with Mexico, Venezuela, Puerto Rico and Morocco – at Parlacen.

;

;But Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega on June 23 proposed in a motion that Parlacen cancel Taipei's observer status and replace it with Beijing.

;

;Ortega, a deputy speaker, reportedly told the parliament that all members except Guatemala recognised Beijing diplomatically so it should be granted observer status instead of Taipei.

;

;Taiwan's foreign ministry last week said Nicaragua was trying to “curry favour” with Beijing.

;

;“By proposing to expel Taiwan so as to let in China, undoubtedly, Nicaragua is once again attempting to curry favour with Beijing in hopes of obtaining economic aid and political support to solve its domestic economic woes,” said Hsiao Kuang-wei, deputy spokesman for the foreign ministry.

;

;He said Ortega had in April last year issued a statement that did not go through the parliamentary review and discussion process declaring that there was only “one China”.

;

;Hsiao said Taiwan had never been ruled by the People's Republic of China and that it was “barbarian and unreasonable” for Beijing to continue using its one-China principle to try to bar Taiwan from taking part in international organisations.

;

;Beijing sees Taiwan as part of its territory that must be brought under its control, by force if necessary. It has ramped up pressure on the self-ruled island – including by poaching its diplomatic allies and staging war games nearby – since Tsai Ing-wen was elected president in 2016 and refused to accept the one-China principle.

;

;Hsiao called for Ortega to stop “placating” Beijing and to return to the democratic and constitutional system.

;

;The proposal is expected to be passed when Parlacen, which is in recess, returns to sessions in August since Guatemala is Taiwan's sole supporter.

;

;Chinese-Americans regard Taiwan more favourably than China: Pew survey

;

;Asked about the situation on Wednesday, Sandra Oudkirk, the de facto US ambassador to Taiwan, told reporters in Taipei that Washington firmly believes the island “has a positive and constructive role to play in the international community”.

;

;She said the US was “fully supportive to Taiwan's participation in international organisations that do not require statehood as a requirement for membership and for meaningful participation, and others like the UN system that requires the status”.

;

;Like most countries, the United States, Taiwan's biggest informal ally and arms supplier, does not recognise the island as an independent state but is opposed to any unilateral change to the status quo by force.

;

;Analysts say if the motion in Parlacen is passed it will be another blow for Taipei in its struggle for international recognition.

;

;“Beijing's influence in Central America is getting stronger every day,” said Max Lo, executive director of the Taiwan International Strategic Study Society, a Taipei think tank.

;

;“With five of Parlacen's six member states maintaining official ties with the mainland, there is not much Taiwan can do other than trying to persuade delegates to exercise their moral courage to vote against the proposal.”

;

;Lo said Beijing was likely to target Guatemala next in its bid to isolate Taipei.

;

;Beijing and Taipei will be closely watching Guatemala's second-round presidential run-off on August 20, when former diplomat and anti-graft candidate Bernardo Arevalo, of the centre-left Semilla party, will face off against centrist and former first lady Sandra Torres, of the social-democratic National Unity of Hope party.

;

;Torres secured 16 per cent of the first-round vote in June, with Arevalo just 4 percentage points behind in second place.

;

;Arevalo has said he would strengthen ties with Beijing if elected, as most countries in the region have done. He told a Guatemala City radio station on June 27 that the country needed “a foreign policy based on its own interests”, and that no one but Guatemala had the right to “dictate the country's position [on its choice of allies]”.

;

;Torres has vowed to continue incumbent President Alejandro Giammattei's policy of maintaining formal relations with Taiwan.

;

;In Taipei, the foreign ministry has said it would do all it could to continue to work with Guatemala to deepen bilateral exchanges and cooperation and pursue the interests of both sides, “regardless of who is elected president”.

;

;Taiwan has just two official partners left in Central America, Guatemala and Belize. They are among a dwindling list of allies – only 13 remain – that still maintain formal diplomatic ties with the island.

;

;Lo noted that Taipei could also lose its observer status at the Central American Integration System – the economic and political body of the member states.

;

;Nicaraguan leader Ortega also called for Taiwan's observer status to be revoked from that body – which it has held since 1992, a year after it was formed – in his statement in April last year.

;

;Beijing's trade deals tempt Taipei's allies in Latin America – but not Pacific

;

;Lo said Beijing had expanded its influence in Latin America, helped by Donald Trump cutting hundreds of millions of dollars in foreign aid to countries in the region when he was US president.

;

;But Washington still has significant influence in the region, with President Joe Biden embracing multilateralism, according to Huang Kwei-bo, a professor of diplomacy at National Chengchi University in Taipei.

;

;“Though the US is no longer as influential as before in some countries like Nicaragua and El Salvador, it is still able to exercise its grip in coordinating with other countries in Latin America when it comes to helping Taiwan in its diplomatic tussle with Beijing,” he said.
